posts.name: Driver (Adept), Build (Timelost)
posts.cooked: My teams controllers has slowly dying and reaching their end, so I’m out here asking for suggestions, it would be great if teams can tell me what controllers you are using and why you are using it, thanks!

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Driver/Programmer/Person that does a little bit of everything

posts.custom_user_title: Driver/Programmer/Person that does a little bit of everything

posts.name: Ian Saam
posts.cooked: Razer Wolverine v2 chroma. Has a bunch of buttons you can remap the face buttons to so I never had to take my thumbs off the joysticks. Also managed to consolidate all controls so we only had one driver this year. Absolutely would recommend if you have the money, they are slightly expensive though.

posts.name: Emeri Pena
posts.cooked: I know a lot of teams who use Logitech controllers, they’re fairly cheap and will last a couple seasons. However a lot of teams who want haptic feedback will usually opt for a ps4/ps5 controller or an xbox 1 controller.

posts.name: Micah
posts.cooked:
Whatever you choose, get something with haptics . I can’t recommend them enough. Haptics (a.k.a. rumble) are one of the best ways to quickly signal something to your driver. They’re even better than LEDs because they don’t require a sight line, and once you start using haptics you’ll never go back. We used them on our robot to signal when we had a note in our intake and when the flywheels were up to speed, and it made a significant impact on our cycle times.

We use Xbox One controllers because they’re reliable, easily replaceable, and have haptics for a pretty good price point. They go on sale frequently as well — for example, you can get them for half off on Black Friday. As a first-party controller they have a nice build quality and feel great to use. Plus, they’re natively supported by Windows, allowing your programming team to become the pro gaming team as soon as the robot breaks.

If you’re trying to decide between an Xbox controller and an Logitech controller, I’d advise against the Logitech controller. While I’ve heard they’re decently reliable and they’re dirt cheap, the lack of haptics and middling build quality are deal breakers for me. Keep in mind though that this advice is coming from someone who thinks that the Logitech controllers look and feel like Happy Meal toys and would much rather spend a week figuring out how to get a Wiimote to work than spend an hour holding a Logitech controller.

If you’re in the market for something high-end, I’d look for a controller with Hall-effect sensors in the joysticks (as they’re super accurate and almost impossible to wear down), extra buttons, or with snapback capacitors to increase accuracy with fast movements. I haven’t done a ton of research in this area though so I can’t recommend anything specific.

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked:
We’ve used the Gulikit Kingkong 2 Pro. One of the best controllers I’ve ever seen. Zero drift, very precise, very comfortable, a zero deadband option for more control and a lot more. @OhFear could elaborate more from his experiences as our driver.

Hyperspace1710:

Whatever you choose, get something with haptics .

Also, I couldn’t recommend this enough. We’ve used it this year to indicate to the driver a note was collected, and it was much better than showing with LEDs or anything else as you can feel it and can respond very fast.

levyishai:

a zero deadband option for more control

From my experience, this mode needs to be enabled every time the controller is turned on, and without it the controller is not very usable.

Spektrum Interlink Dx for driver and a PS5 controller for operator.

The InterLink DX Simulator Controller with USB Plug from Spektrum, the leader in spread spectrum radio control.

link_counts.title: InterLink DX Simulator Controller with USB Plug | Spektrum

posts.name: Zachary
posts.cooked: Previously, we used Logitech F310s (for basically as long as the team has existed), but after a number issues (I don’t remember the specifics, but everything from D-pad to deadbanding, etc), we switched to the Xbox Wireless Controller , which has been a very solid upgrade. The drive team likes them, they’re simple to program, they have rumble, and the name of the white color is “Robot White”, so you know it’ll work well for robotics.

posts.name: Sean Lavery
posts.cooked: Spark Max
Afaik these are illegal to bring onto the field unless you’ve disabled the wireless functionality somehow.

posts.name: Zachary
posts.cooked: You never need to put batteries into it!
Do you know for sure that the Bluetooth chip is disabled when there are no batteries?

posts.name: Zachary
posts.cooked: Honestly, I have no idea. If it is on, then LOTS of teams are going to be in trouble.

posts.name: Peter Matteson
posts.cooked:
For our SWERVE base we use these…

Best Optimal Joystick For Swerve? Programming

For our operator we switched to these this year…

My new website

These are so much better built and more reliable than the Logitech controllers. These last a season and the Logitech ones maybe lasted 2 events before having issues.
my team uses the Xbox Elite Series 2 Controller . this started last year when I was driving with my personal controller but now the team bought one so @JaiCodes could stop dropping mine.

posts.name: Thomas Baeyens
posts.cooked: We’ve been using a fully custom setup for the last couple years. While it does work, I would actually strongly recommend against doing this for most teams, as it is quite a nuisance to deal with, and also kind of unreliable sometimes

I don’t doubt that, but per the letter of the law rules it’s illegal. I think the rule is bad and needs to be changed but as it is it’s problematic to use controllers with wireless capabilities. @flametek note that the elite controller falls under this rule.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: Wolverine V2.  Love 'em.

posts.name: John Fogarty
posts.cooked:
https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0BZRFRJ4X?ref=ppx_yo2ov_dt_b_product_details&th=1

We use these Xbox controllers. They are nice because they also include some extra buttons on the bottom you can add functions to.

We have moved away from Xbox controllers with detachable wires due to experiences where if the driver station was hit hard enough the controller wires would come unplugged or other instances where the controller wire was not seated properly. Funny enough I was watching a video from Hacksmith’s battlebots team and they switched to using the same controller for the exact same reason.

posts.name: Andy Mundell
posts.cooked:
We do xBox for a couple reasons.

Many students are used to these controllers.

They have rumble features.

If one breaks at competition, we can just run to the nearest Target and get a new one.
